security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The skill runs a simple Ruby script that outputs a greeting. The 'external_commands' flag refers to documentation showing a bash command, not actual backtick execution. The 'weak cryptographic algorithm' alerts are incorrect pattern matches on YAML description fields containing the word 'description'. No security concerns confirmed.

content.value_statement: Users need a simple way to create personalized greeting messages in Ruby. This skill provides a lightweight Ruby script that outputs a customizable greeting with the user's name and Ruby version information.
actual_capabilities: Outputs a personalized greeting with the provided name
Displays the Ruby version in the output
Uses command-line arguments for name input
Provides a default greeting when no name is specified
limitations: Only outputs to standard output, no file writes
Simple string output only, no complex logic
Fixed greeting format, limited customization options

use_cases.title: Quick Ruby Testing
use_cases.description: Verify Ruby runtime is available and working by running a simple script that produces output.

use_cases.title: Template for Ruby Scripts
use_cases.description: Use as a starting point for learning Ruby scripting patterns and command-line argument handling.
use_cases.target_user: Ruby beginners learning to write scripts

use_cases.title: Simple AI Output Demo
use_cases.description: Demonstrate how AI agents can generate and execute simple programs to produce formatted output.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Greeting
prompt_templates.prompt: Run the enact-hello-ruby skill to greet Alice
prompt_templates.scenario: Simple request to generate a greeting

prompt_templates.title: Custom Name
prompt_templates.prompt: Use enact-hello-ruby to say hello to [your name here]

prompt_templates.title: Integration Test
prompt_templates.prompt: Run enact-hello-ruby and capture the output for verification
prompt_templates.scenario: Checking skill execution in a workflow

best_practices: Provide a name parameter for personalized greetings
Handle missing input gracefully with a default value
Include version information for debugging purposes
Keep the output format simple and readable
anti_patterns: Do not pass untrusted input directly without understanding the execution context
Avoid assuming this skill can modify files or access network resources
Do not expect complex logic or conditional formatting in the output

faq.question: What does this skill do?
faq.answer: It runs a simple Ruby script that outputs a greeting message with the provided name and shows the Ruby version.

faq.question: How do I use it?
faq.answer: Provide a name parameter. If no name is given, it defaults to 'World'. Example: enact-hello-ruby with name=Alice.

faq.question: Does it write to files?
faq.answer: No, it only outputs to standard output. It does not create or modify any files.

faq.question: Can it access the network?
faq.answer: No, this skill has no network capabilities. It only runs a simple Ruby script locally.

faq.question: What Ruby versions are supported?
faq.answer: The skill runs on any Ruby 3.x version. It will display the installed Ruby version in the output.

faq.question: Is this skill safe to use?
faq.answer: Yes, this is a read-only skill that performs no file writes, network requests, or system modifications.
